head.symptom: Throbbing head pain often associated with nausea as well as sensitivity to light and sound.
Dull, aching head pain often associated with tenderness in the neck, scalp, and shoulder muscles.

midUpperBack.symptom: Pain off to one side of the spine often made worse with deep breaths, laughing, coughing, or sneezing.

neck.symptom: Generalized neck pain often made worse with when the head is turned or bent to the side.
Neck, shoulder, and arm pain often associated with numbness or tingling into the arm, hand, or fingers.
Neck, shoulder, and arm pain often associated with numbness or tingling into the arm, hand, or fingers.

shoulder.symptom: Pain in the shoulder that is made worse with overhead and/or pushing motions.
Pain in front of the shoulder that sometimes radiates down to the elbow and may be associated with a clicking or snapping feeling.
Progressive loss of shoulder motion initially associated with pain.
Pain on the top of the shoulder aggravated by heavy lifting, overhead, and across body movements.

elbow.symptom: Pain from the elbow to the wrist on the palm side of the forearm.
Pain on the back side of the elbow and along the thumb side of the forearm.

wrist.symptom: Wrist discomfort often associated with tingling, numbness, and/or weakness in the fingers or hands.
Pain near the base of the thumb generally made worse when attempting to grasp or pinch something.
Pain, tenderness, or swelling on the thumb side of the wrist.
Tingling in the palm and 4th and 5th fingers often associated with weakness or tenderness in the hand.

excerStretchInnerThigh.name: excerStretchInnerThigh
excerStretchInnerThigh.title: Exercises & Stretches for the Inner Thigh

excerStretchLowerLegFoot.name: excerStretchLowerLegFoot
excerStretchLowerLegFoot.title: Exercises & Stretches for the Lower Leg/Foot

excerStretchNeck.purpose: Strengthen the muscles at the front of the neck.
startingPosition: 1. Sit or stand tall with your shoulders relaxed.
2. Place one of your hands on your forehead.
3. Tuck your chin as if trying to give yourself a double chin.
keyToSuccess: 1. Keep your chin tucked (as if trying to give yourself a double chin) throughout the exercise.
2. Maintain proper posture.
3. Don’t push too hard with your head as this could lead to injury.
4. Make sure to relax and breath through your stomach.
commonErrors: 1. Hunching the shoulders towards the ears.
reccomendedFor: 1. Post whiplash injuries (under doctor supervision initially).
